answers.body_markdown:
None of the builtin accessors will do what you want. You can build your own accessor and monkey-patch it in:

	def get(df, **kwargs):
	    cond = [True] * df.shape[0]
	    for col, value in kwargs.items():
	        cond &= df[col] == value
        
	    result = df[cond]
	    if result.shape[0] > 1:
	        raise ValueError('Key must be unique')
	    return result.iloc[0]
	
	pd.DataFrame.get = get
	
	# Usage
	df.get(col1=..., col2=..., col3=...)
	
This is relatively slow, however, so don't call it in a tight loop.

answers.body_markdown:
The answer was simple. Put `RewriteRule ^([^\.]+)$ $1.php [NC,L]` at the end of the file, else it's kind of mixing with the other rules.

    RewriteEngine On
    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f
    RewriteRule ^events/([^/]+)$ viewevent.php?c=$1 [L,QSA]
    RewriteCond %{HTTPS} off
    RewriteRule (.*) https://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [R=301,L]
    RewriteRule ^([^\.]+)$ $1.php [NC,L]
answers.title: Why does echoing htaccess-value end with file-ending?

answers.body_markdown:
Your rules need more reordering otherwise in present state it will redirect `http://example.com/events/foo` to `https://example.com/viewevent.php?c=foo` thus exposing your internal handler.

Moreover you need to add `.php` for files that actually exist in your filesystem as php file.

You may use this code:

    RewriteEngine On
    
    RewriteCond %{HTTPS} off
    RewriteRule ^ https://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [R=301,L,NE]
    
    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f
    RewriteRule ^events/([^/]+)/?$ viewevent.php?c=$1 [L,NC,QSA]
    
    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-d
    RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME}.php -f
    RewriteRule ^(.+?)/?$ $1.php [L]

answers.body_markdown:
The question becomes, why are there two tables in the first place? If both tables are always 1 to 1 (every time a row goes into first table it must also always go into second table) then yes, combine them, save the space of the duplicate data and indexes. If it is possible for the two tables to have different entries (one always a row per "incident" but the other may not or data sometimes in first table and sometimes in second) the keep them as two to minimize the dead space per row. The data should drive the table designs. You don't say how many rows you are talking. If the rows, tables, and DB are small, does it really matter other than trying to design well (always a good idea)?

Another related consideration is how much data is already in the current design and how much effort is needed to convert to a different design? Is it worth the effort? I prefer to normalize the data "mostly" (am not fanatical about it) but also tend to not mess with what isn't broken.

Sorry if you were wanting a more clear-cut answer...
answers.title: Should i combine two table become one table to improve query performance

 2. I am prepared for send() to return EWOULDBLOCK/EAGAIN in a minority of cases (in which case I just defer the write of the message to an asynchronous thread using a mutex protected queuing structure)
 3. I cannot get mutexes on these foreground writing threads (apart from the EWOULDBLOCK/EAGAIN cases), as the implied cache flushes give me an unacceptable CPU impact (this also means no use of other synchronization objects to work around the problem, such as atomic integers).
 4. As far as I know, I cannot guarantee that send() won't decide to write some, but not all of any given message, thus resulting in (potentially) interleaved data

answers.body_markdown:
a couple of background points:

 * [statistics](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/planner-stats.html) look good, i.e. it's guessing roughly how many rows it'll get back and seems to be propagating this information correctly.  this is important because lots of times the query planner does the "wrong thing" because it doesn't have a very good idea of the data in the table

 * 1.8 seconds (i.e. ~90% of the time) is spent executing `Parallel Bitmap Heap Scan on clicks`, this is fetching the actual data from the table that the index scan identified as relevant

while executing this query PG is therefore likely spending most of its time doing IO, and only a small amount amount of time processing the data.  the aim would therefore be to either make it read the data more efficiently or just to read less data

 * creating an index specifically for this query, as suggested by @Bergi,  would allow PG not to read the data from the table but this will only tend to optimise a few specific queries, see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/indexes-index-only-scans.html for the official docs

 * random access is much slower than sequential, so you could try rearranging the table to optimise for this query, e.g. see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-cluster.html but this comes with lots of caveats and probably won't help you long term (but is sometimes useful!)

 * normalising your table so rows don't take as much storage space can help, but if rows are still randomly scattered throughout the table then this isn't going to help much

 * a faster IO subsystem, especially something that can do faster random IO, will help everything, but will obviously cost more on an ongoing basis

 * cache results, if you're doing this a lot you can save the results into a different table (or "materialised view") and use that rather than going to the source data all the time

basically what's "best" depends on quite a few things, I'd suggest searching for a few of the terms I've used and reading about them if you're new to this sort of stuff

> I can't understand why TypeScript fails to see that source and destination are the same type and that we use the same key-type.

I don't truly know if this case can't be solved by TypeScript, but what I know is that TypeScript's compiler (or any other language under certain constraints) [can't check every possible truth][1] (in this case, that those elements are equal). This seems to be your case. 

> But how else are we supposed to do it then?

Sometimes, humans need to give hints to the compiler. In this case, I'd use `any` to stop the compiler to report errors. 


  [1]: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/14833

answers.title: Implicit scala class with generics

answers.body_markdown:
I don't see much difference than above, here is another alternative using `CanBuildFrom`

```scala
import scala.collection.generic._
import scala.language.higherKinds
implicit class CollWrapper[Coll[X] <: Traversable[X], A](coll:Coll[A]) {
    def peek(f:A => Unit)(implicit cbf:CanBuildFrom[Coll[A], A, Coll[A]]):Coll[A] = {
       val builder = cbf(coll)
       coll.foreach{elem =>
          builder += elem;
          f(elem)
       }
       coll
    }
}

List(1,2,3,4).peek(println).map(x => x * 3)
println("--")
List("One", "Two", "Three").peek(println).map(x => x + "!")
println("--")
List('c', 'd', 'e').peek(println).map(x => x + 3)
println("--")
Set("Nine", "Ten", "Twelve").peek(println).map(x => x + "!")
println("--")
Map(1 -> "One", 2 -> "Two", 3 -> "Three").peek(println).map{case (k,v) => (k, v + "!")}.toMap
println("--")
```
answers.title: Implicit scala class with generics

items.body_markdown:
I have this code:

```
object Peek {
    implicit def traversableToPeek[A](underlying: Traversable[A]) = new Peek(underlying)
}
class Peek[A](underlying: Traversable[A]) {

    /**
     * Java-style peek method
     */
    def peek(func: A => Unit): Traversable[A] = {
        underlying.foreach(func)
        underlying
    }
}
```
while lets me write things like `List(1,2,3).peek(println).map(_+1).peek(println)` which prints 1,2,3 and then 2,3,4 (after `import Peek._`)

However, the compile-time value of that expression is `Traversable[Int]`.  This means that while this code compiles:

```
val l = List(1,2,3)
val l2 = 4 :: l
```
this code does not:
```
val l = List(1,2,3).peek(println)
val l2 = 4 :: l
```

since `::` is not defined on `Traversable`.  The intent of peek is to allow side-effect only operations without requiring somewhat ugly constructs like `l.map(e => println(e); e)`

I tried adding a second generic parameter `T <: Traversable` or `T[A] <: Traversable[A]` but could not get it compile in a manner where the implicit conversion worked.

I feel this should be possible, but I am not familiar enough with Scala to get the syntax correct.
items.title: Implicit scala class with generics

answers.body_markdown:
Short answer:

Your delete query has a syntax error.   This was hinted at in the comments... 

Youâ€™re also mixing server side and client side by trying to use JavaScript in a php class. Thatâ€™s a major mistake and requires some going back to review the basics. 

Long answer:

I perceive youâ€™re trying to move towards OOP programming, and youâ€™re doing some things right; notably, injecting the database connection into your crud object. 

But thereâ€™s some things that could be done better.  Hereâ€™s a few ideasâ€”

1.  [Use PDO][1] instead of mysqli, and ***use prepared statements***. Very likely this would have eliminated the syntax error in the query. 
2.  Always return json encoded data from Ajax requests. I personally always have the php script respond with something like `return json_encode( ['message'=>$message, 'data'=>$data] );`. Then your JavaScript back in the browser can decide what to communicate to the user. 
3.  Methods should do One Thing. If the method gets bigger than what fits on the screen, you probably need to refactor.  For example, `getRecords()` checks for page number, creates a query, gets total number, and gets all records. This should probably be broken up into separate methods, or better yet, create a pagination object that could be injected into the query creation method. 

BTW, to illustrate how important the prepared statements are:  what if someone went to `hxxp://yourdomain/exam_package_response.php?action=delete&edit_pkg_id=1+or+1%3D1`?

Answer:  ***you just lost all the data in this table***.  Prepared statements will prevent this.
  [1]: https://phpdelusions.net/pdo#prepared

answers.body_markdown:
Here's something that works for generic number of inputs and relevant einsum-expression and also works for the specific scalar reduction case -

    def einsum_outshape(einsum_expr, inputs):
        shps = np.concatenate([in_.shape for in_ in inputs])
        p = einsum_expr.split(',')
        s = p[:-1] + p[-1].split('->')
        if s[-1]=='':
            return ()
        else:
            inop = list(map(list,s))
            return tuple(shps[(np.concatenate(inop[:-1])[:,None]==inop[-1]).argmax(0)])

Sample run -

    In [42]: a = np.random.rand(1,2,5)
        ...: b = np.random.rand(4,5)
        ...: c = np.random.rand(5,7,8)
        ...: d = np.random.rand(7,9)
    
    In [43]: einsum_outshape('ijk,mk,kpq,pr->ikpqr', inputs=(a,b,c,d))
    Out[43]: (1, 5, 7, 8, 9)
    
    # Reduction to a scalar
    In [44]: einsum_outshape('ijk,mk,kpq,pr->', inputs=(a,b,c,d))
    Out[44]: ()

answers.title: messed up lua paths after trying to set up debugging

answers.body_markdown:
The default values for both paths are located in [luaconf.h#LUA_PATH_DEFAULT][1] ff. (5.3).

That being said - your `LUA_CPATH` misses two things from the default one: `LUA_CDIR/loadall.so` and `./?.so`. In your case the problem is due to lack of the second one.

That is because the `./kodev run` do some additional actions to set-up runtime environment. At some point the working directory is changed to `EMU_DIR` (e.g. `./koreader-emulator-x86_64-linux-gnu-debug/koreader`). This very directory also has a valid `libs/libkoreader-lfs.so`.

Change `LUA_CPATH` to contain `./?.so`:

    export LUA_CPATH="$ZBS/bin/linux/x86/?.so;$ZBS/bin/linux/x86/clibs/?.so;./?.so"


  [1]: https://www.lua.org/source/5.3/luaconf.h.html#LUA_PATH_DEFAULT
answers.title: messed up lua paths after trying to set up debugging

answers.body_markdown:
@NicolasR's comment is right on the money. You need to adjust your bot code to handle the new intents. You can do this a couple of different ways:

### 1. Online Editor (not recommended, at all)

Go to `Azure Portal > Your Resource Group > Your App Service > App Service Editor`:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

Then edit the files under `wwwroot`. If your bot is in C#, you'll need to open the console:

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

Then execute `dotnet build`, then click Run:

[![enter image description here][3]][3]

### 2. Local Editor (highly recommended)

Go to `Azure Portal > Your Resource Group > Your Web App Bot > Build > Download Source Code`:

[![enter image description here][4]][4]

Then, open the code in the editor of your choice (I recommend [Visual Studio](https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads/) or [VS Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/download) -- both are free), edit the code to account for your new intents, then [Deploy your bot to Azure](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/bot-service/bot-builder-deploy-az-cli?view=azure-bot-service-4.0&tabs=csharp).

This is much, much better in the long-run as you develop your bot.

---

### Update

Without actually seeing more of your code, I believe you need to edit your intents into [LuisHelper](https://github.com/microsoft/BotBuilder-Samples/blob/010532c3477c7ae82ab95f494f395712f0646d93/samples/csharp_dotnetcore/13.core-bot/LuisHelper.cs#L36)

That being said, I'm relatively sure this far more advanced that what you're ready for. I recommend downloading some [samples](https://github.com/microsoft/BotBuilder-Samples/tree/master/samples/csharp_dotnetcore), and start with the first few to see how they work, then try to get CoreBot working locally.

[Here's some additional information](https://stackoverflow.com/a/55618660/10860086) about getting started.

answers.body_markdown:
While there are lots of problems with that HTML, the core issue is that the browser doesn't think it is HTML. 

Since you are loading it from a file path (and not an HTTP(S) URL) this will be because you gave it a file extension that is not `.html` (although whatever you did use is cut-off in the screenshot). Possibly you have `behaviour.html.txt` or similar.

Rename the file.

You should probably also change your editor (e.g. to Visual Studio Code). Whatever you are using is probably responsible for your use of `â€œ` and `â€` where you need `"` and the wrong file extension.

My while loop only works the second time instead of first

answers.body_markdown:
You're asking for input a second time inside the loop. You should only do that if the input wasn't one of the valid choices.

You should use `and` rather than `or` to test the input. See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26337003/execute-block-if-a-variable-is-not-one-of-some-specific-values

Finally, you should process the input *after* the loop, since that's when it will contain a valid choice.
```
option=input("Would you like to login or signup?: ")
while option != "signup" and option != "login":
    option=input("Would you like to login or signup?: ")

if option == "signup":
    signup()
elif option == "login":
    login()

Next, you need to make actions; these have the options of executing code in a completion handler after the actions button has been pressed

        let yourAction = UIAlertAction(title: "Save", style: .default) { (action) in
            //Your code that wishes to be executed after the butt has been pressed
        }

Then, add the action into the controller

    avc.addAction(yourAction)

then all you need to do is present the alert

    present(avc, animated: true, completion: nil)

answers.body_markdown:
You are using the option "**Begin with**". This option is also assigned to individual steps in the funnel. The problem is that all your step start with "*shop.aap.org/cart/*". Therefore when Analytics verifies the correspondence with the paths it always finds it at the first step and stops there.

For the functioning of that particular funnel, the sessions they convert also fill all the previous steps.

If you want to learn more, I wrote some days ago an article that explains your problem exactly:
https://www.analyticstraps.com/quando-la-visualizzazione-canalizzazione-mente/
note: the article is in Italian, translate it into your language if necessary.

In your case you can try using "**Regex**" instead of "**Begin with**" and adjusting paths accordingly.

The issue is that PowerShell v2 is not recognizing the standard date/time formats for `TimeSpan`. (I put `Start-Sleep -Seconds 2` to have some timediff).

PowerShell 2 output:

    Duration: 00:00:02.0001144 h 00:00:02.0001144 min 00:00:02.0001144 sec

PowerShell 5 output:

    Duration: 00 h 00 min 02 sec

You can format "manually" specifing the TimeSpan properties:

    $ElapsedTime = ('Duration: {0} h {1} min {2} sec' -f $elapsed.Hours, $elapsed.Minutes, $elapsed.Seconds)


Works in both versions.

CLRS states two equivalent ways of forming the subproblems for the rod cutting problem:

    r(n) = max(r(1) + r(n-1), r(2) + r(n-2),...,r(n-1) + r(1), p(n))

and

    r(n) = max(p(1) + r(n-1), p(2) + r(n-2),...,p(n-1) + r(1), p(n))

where `r(i)` is the maximum revenue possible to cut a rod of length `i`, and `p(i)` is the price of a rod of length `i`.

What I'm not able to work out is how the two are equivalent. Can someone provide a proof?
